Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Plant Nuclear Envelope Interactome

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proteins of the plant nuclear envelope have important roles in many cell functions, including mechanical signaling, controlling the shape and movement of the nucleus, and the cell cycle. However, for reasons that are not currently understood, the protein composition of the plant nuclear envelope differs significantly from that of the animals and fungi. The goal of this project is to understand the function of the novel plant-specific proteins that span the nuclear envelope, and which are predicted to play roles in plant development, pollination, and the responses to light and pathogens. The experimental approaches will include live-cell imaging by light microscopy, and the identification of the protein interaction partners using techniques of affinity chromatography, tandem mass spectrometry and computational biology.
Broader Impacts. A novel course in biology and art will be developed, in collaboration with an Art professor at Ohio State University, with the goal to make topics in contemporary plant biology accessible and comprehensible to the public. A public Bio-Art exhibit will be developed and the course will form the basis for a module that can be used by high school teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In each cell, the nucleus is a membrane-enclosed compartment that houses the genetic material of the cell. The membranes surrounding and confining the nucleus are called the nuclear envelope. My lab studies the proteins associated with the nuclear envelope. Specifically, we ask if, during evolution, plants and animals have acquired different proteins and what that tells us about their function and about the function of the nuclear envelope. This funding has allowed us to discover several new proteins complexes at the plant nuclear envelope and to begin to understand their function. For example, one complex is required for the transport of the pollen nucleus through the stigma and style of the flower. When this process is disrupted, plants have reduced male fertility, and thus seed (grain) production is also reduced. Another complex is involved in the function of guard cells, the cell pairs in the leaf epidermis that regulate the uptake of carbon dioxide and release of oxygen. Importantly, while some subunits of these complexes are conserved between plants and animals, others are unique to plants. This allows us to discover plant-specific cellular functions of molecules which are much more broadly investigated in animals and humans, because they are also related to inherited human diseases.

 

Because one of the subunits of the complex is anchored to the inner membrane of the nuclear envelope, we also need to understand how a protein is transported to this location. Towards that goal, we have investigated what signals embedded in the protein’s amino acid sequence are required to transport a membrane-associated protein from the cytoplasm to the nucleus in plants. We have defined rules for this transport process and have engineered chimeric proteins that do not exist in nature and that are anchored to the inner membrane of the nuclear envelope. These can now serve as tools to attach other functional units to them, which will allow us to add novel functionality to this specific part of the cell.
